awd_titl_txt: Pinpointing with a Broad Beam: h/m and the Fine Structure Constant
awd_abstract_narration:
The fine structure constant characterizes the strength of the electromagnetic interaction and is ubiquitous in physics. It has been measured using methods from across physics, whose agreement is a powerful confirmation of the consistency of theory and experiment. Using well-measured fundamental constants (the Rydberg constant and atomic mass ratios), the fine structure constant can be related to the recoil velocity of an atom that has scattered a photon. This project will use this relationship in order to measure the fine structure constant with the highest precision ever. This will allow the research team to test several extensions of the standard model, such as dark matter candidates, and probe for a substructure of the electron, to test if the electron is indeed an elementary particle. The measurement of the recoil velocity (which is inversely proportional to the atomic mass) can also be used as an ultra-precise realization of the unit of mass and thus a cornerstone of the revised international system of units.
  
This experiment is based on an atom interferometer. It uses a broad laser beam which comes extremely close to the ideal case of an infinite electromagnetic plane wave. A powerful pulsed laser will be available for this project, as well as an atomic fountain accommodating the beam. A new geometry for the atom interferometer will be used, vertically offset simultaneous conjugate interferometers (OSCIs). This will cancel the effects of vibrations, gravity, and even the gravity gradient. The project will measure h/m using a combination of Bragg diffraction and Bloch oscillations with cesium atoms at an accuracy of 0.02 ppb. From h/m, the fine structure constant will be determined with a target accuracy of 0.039 ppb, limited by the accuracy of mAt/me. It is hoped that that improvements in the cesium or electron mass measurement will reduce the error in the fine structure constant to 0.02 ppb. Already now, such measurements of the fine structure constant set stringent limits on several proposed particles. For example, scalar and pseudoscalar bosons, vector bosons, dark photons, hidden-sector photons, and axial-vector bosons would all be discoverable. This tests the standard model of particle physics broadly and deeply.

por.por_cntn:
Every physicist knows the approximate value (~1/137) of a fundamental constant called the fine-structure constant, α. This constant describes the strength of the electromagnetic force between elementary particles in the standard model of particle physics and is therefore central to the foundations of physics. For example, the magnetic moment of an electron is subtly larger than that expected for a charged, point-like particle by a factor of roughly 1 + α/(2π). This ‘anomaly’ of the magnetic moment has been verified to ever-increasing accuracy, becoming “the standard model’s greatest triumph”


By 2020, the leading measurements of α and of the gyromagnetic anomaly were all in agreement. Laboratoire Kastler-Brossel (LKB-11) in Paris had measured α with a rubidium atom interferometry with 660 ppt accuracy while the Gabrielse group had measured the gyromagnetic anomaly to 250 ppt . In 2018, our group published what was at the time the most accurate measurement of α, at 200 ppt. This was also the first measurement of α using the new method of large momentum transfer, an important advance in the art of atom interferometry. In 2020, however, a new measurement of α was reported by LKB, which differed from Berkeley-18 at the level of 5.4 standard deviations. The discrepancy is frustrating what could be the most accurate test of the standard model. This makes it extremely important to re-measure the fine-structure constant and explore the origin of the discrepancy. 


The major goal of this project is to measure the fine-structure constant. To this end, we are measuring the mass of cesium atoms to extreme precision, using an atom interferometer that employs a combination of Bragg diffraction and Bloch oscillations. Combining this value with the known values of the cesium-to-electron mass ratio as well as the Rydberg constant yields the fine structure constant with a target accuracy of 0.04 ppb.


During the course of the project, we have demonstrated major new technologies towards improving the accuracy of atom interferometers. The first is a new atom-interferometry configuration that is insensitive to the gravity gradient [W. Zhong, R. H. Parker, Z. Pagel, C. Yu, and H. Müller, Offset Simultaneous Conjugate Atom Interferometers, Phys. Rev. A 101, 053622 (2020)]. This usually produces a systematic that increases with the third power of the atom’s time-of-flight, making it difficult to increase the sensitivity of the atom interferometer, which is proportional to the time-of-flight. The second is extending the concept of Bloch oscillations to two superposed optical lattices that are accelerated away from one another. This allows us to split, reflect, and recombine matter waves coherently. Using the parity symmetry of the Hamiltonian, we map out the energy band structure of the process and show that superpositions of momentum states are created by adiabatically following the ground state of the Hamiltonian. The relative phase and velocity of the two lattices completely determines the trajectories of different branches of the matter wave. Experimentally we demonstrate symmetric Bloch oscillations using cold cesium atoms where we form interferometers with up to 240⁢ℏ⁢𝑘 momentum splitting, one of the largest coherent momentum splittings achieved to date. This work has applications in macroscopic tests of quantum mechanics, measurements of fundamental constants, and searches for new physics [Z. Pagel, W. Zhong, R. H. Parker, C. T. Olund, N. Y. Yao, and H. Müller, Symmetric Bloch Oscillations of Matter Waves, Phys. Rev. A 102, 053312 (2020)].


In the final year, we finished setting up the experiment and demonstrated its suitability for long-term data taking. Like no other current experiment, it is capable of measuring alpha at the utmost precision by overcoming the main limitation of the [previous generation of alpha measurements: the degree to which large- and small-scale distortions of the laser beam can be suppressed and characterized. It accomplishes this by a large-diameter vacuum chamber offering an 8-inch clear aperture to the laser beam (5x that of the predecessor), a black copper-oxide coating as well as baffles to capture stray beams. Full characterization of the experiment and its systematic effects is now underway, getting ready for a next measurement of the fine-structure constant.
